Temporal Presence Variation in Immersive Computer Games

Jaeyong Chung The Australian National University , Canberra , Australia Correspondencejae.chung@anu.edu.au
 & Henry J. Gardner The Australian National University , Canberra , Australia
Pages 511-529
Accepted author version posted online: 29 Mar 2012
Published online:21 Jun 2012
  • Download citation
  • https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.627298

            Temporal Presence Variation in Immersive Computer Games

            • Full Article
            • Figures & data
            • References

            • Metrics

            • PDF

            Abstract

            Increasingly, the sophistication of modern computer-gaming systems is becoming comparable to that of immersive, virtual reality (VR) environments, and the popular VR research topic of “presence” is now being explored in the context of computer games. The explosion of popularity of networked gameplay and the movement of computing infrastructure on to the Internet and the cloud mean that technical anomalies such as network latency, dropouts, and so on, may increasingly disrupt players' experience of presence. In this article, a study of these “Breaks in Presence” (BIPs), which examines a networked, first-person-shooter game in an immersive virtual environment, is presented. Our study investigates how participants react to BIPs in terms of their impact on participants' levels of presence and in terms of the time needed for participants to recover from BIPs. Four distinct BIP types, which were selected because of their practical significance and because of their relevance to an established model for presence, were tested. The effects of two contrasting game modes (a low-involvement “navigation game” and a high-involvement “combat game”) on the perceptions of these BIPs are analyzed. As part of our experimental procedure a new video-cued-recall slider technique is introduced.

            Our study shows that participants experience different levels of impact and recovery from BIPs and that the perceptions of impact of BIPs depend on the overall sense of presence as well as being task dependent. The article shows that recovery time seems to be a well-defined concept and that an overall measure of recovery time exhibits believable correlations with overall presence, with the overall number of BIPs (including “spontaneous” BIPs) and with user characteristics. The article also shows that the slider data for recovery time from BIPs provide evidence for a smooth variation of presence during an immersive experience. It is found that perceptions of impact and recovery time behave differently and that, intriguingly, recovery time appears to be much more independent of game mode than impact is. Evidence is found of strong carry-over effects in participants' recollections of the impact of BIPs from one game experience to the next is found. Results from our slider technique appear to show general agreement with results from a postexperiment questionnaire, and our study motivates the usefulness of our slider technique for future experiments.

            1. BACKGROUND AND MOTIVATION

            The increasing technological sophistication of gaming systems and the increasing artistic sophistication of gaming content are ushering in new possibilities of user experience. Many modern video games contain complex plots, involve new and skilled interaction techniques, and include collaboration with remote players and intelligent agents. The cost of display and interaction technology is decreasing dramatically, and some gaming platforms now include surround screens and 3D stereo graphics. In their sophistication, such gaming systems are comparable to immersive, virtual reality (VR) environments, and several researchers have been investigating the commonalities between these two areas. In particular, the concept of “presence,” which has long been associated with research in virtual reality, is being explored in the context of computer games (Gajadhar, Kort, & IJsselsteijin, 2008; Jennett, Cox, & Cairns, 2008; McMahan, 2003; Nowak, Krcmar, & Farrar, 2008; Pinchbeck, 2005; Ravaja et al., 2006; Retaux, 2003; Skalski, Lange, & Tamborini, 2006; Vorderer & Bryant, 2006) and in other applications (e.g., Nah, Eschenbrenner, & DeWester, 2011; Song, Fiore, & Park, 2007). These studies broadly conclude that a high level of presence, the mental state of feeling “transported into the game,” enhances player enjoyment.

            Somewhat curiously, the steady improvements in gaming platforms and game design are not always associated with improved reliability. Indeed, the explosion of popularity of networked gameplay, the expansion of these networks to have global reach and the movement of computing resources onto cloud-based platforms all imply that “technical anomalies” of one sort or another may distract from the game experience. These anomalies include latency or pixelizing of the visual display, audio drop-outs, lack of synchronization between controls and feedback, and so on. They have the potential to significantly disrupt the presence experience can lead to “Breaks in Presence” (BIPs). Clearly, designing platforms and network infrastructure to minimize, or otherwise control, the effects of BIPs is a modern challenge for games designers.

            In the VR research community, “spontaneous” BIPs have been studied to understand the nature of the transition between the two alternative “gestalts” of the virtual world and the real, physical environment (Schloerb, 1994; Slater & Steed, 2000; Wirth et al., 2007). Slater and Steed (2000) first introduced the BIPs concept in a paper that modeled spontaneous BIPs stochastically on the assumption that binary transitions from the virtual to the real world would take place according to a probability distribution (although the authors stressed that the binary-state assumption was not something that they would defend as a true model of the underlying psychological processes). Spagnolli and Gamberini (2002) subsequently used a discursive and interaction analysis of spontaneous BIPs to show that participants could remain focused on interaction in the virtual environment in spite of being conscious of the real world and they suggested that the “hybridity” of the virtual and real environments should be taken into account in VR design and evaluation. In a further study, Brogni, Slater, and Steed (2003) then showed that “low presence” was associated with more BIPs, and more recently, a study of “high-immersion” and “low-immersion” computer games has shown that participants in the low-immersion (or, loosely speaking, “weak-presence”) condition recorded more audio distractions (Jennett, Cox, & Cairns, 2009). Furthermore, as discussed in section 1.2, other studies have attempted to correlate subjective, participant-reported BIPs with objective, physiological diagnostics.

            The work described in this article set out to systematically assess the effects of different types of induced BIPs on the experience of computer games in an immersive, VR theatre. The BIPs were selected to target the main theoretical determinants of presence (for the first time in the literature, to our knowledge) and we studied both the impact and the recovery from BIPs as experienced by participants.

            In the remainder of this section, we provide the motivation behind the general hypotheses tested in our experiment. We start by describing a conceptual model for the phenomenon of presence in section 1.1. We then describe ways that other researchers have measured presence and BIP, in section 1.2, before introducing our video-recalled-slider technique in section 1.3. Motivated by work which has shown that the experience of presence itself is a main determinant on the experience of BIPs, and motivated by the clear features in our slider traces corresponding to impact and recovery from BIPs, we then describe our general experimental hypotheses in section 1.4. Subsequent sections of this article provide the details of the experimental method (in section. 2) and the main experimental results (in section. 3). The main trends in our results are discussed in section. 4, and the article concludes with section. 5. Appendices provide details of the questionnaires used and expand on the details of the experimental results.

            1.1. A Conceptual Model for Presence

            In the context of computer games, “presence” has been commonly thought of as the psychological feeling of being transported away from reality and into the virtual world of the game (Ivory & Kalyanaraman, 2007; McMahan, 2003; Nowak et al., 2008; Park & Hwang, 2009; Ravaja et al., 2006; Retaux, 2003; Skalski et al., 2006). Although only one of the six concepts of presence identified in the review of the literature by Lombard and Ditton (1997), the notion of “being there” has also been dominant in investigations of presence in VR environments. As surveyed in Lessiter, Freeman, Keogh, and Davidoff (2001), VR researchers have found it convenient to conceptualize the various determinants underlying presence to be either objective characteristics of the “media” or subjective “user characteristics” (e.g., Freeman & Avons, 2000; IJsselsteijn & Riva, 2003; Slater, Steed, McCarthy, & Maringelli 1998) and, furthermore, media characteristics have been decomposed into characteristics of media content and media form. A clear exposition of this conceptual model for presence can be found in IJsselsteijn and Riva (2003), and their exposition is used as a reference point for the development of the rest of this article.

            Clearly, the media content of computer games has the potential to be highly involving, and it is reasonable to study how a highly involving computer game can potentially transport players away from reality. Tamborini et al. (2004) argued that an active role in decisions to engage in combat led to greater involvement in game playing than passively watching a game. Their results also indicated that a higher interactivity of game playing (e.g., in combat) was associated with a higher reported experience of presence. Some researchers have investigated the effects of playing “violent” video games on presence. Nowak et al. (2008) suggested that players who perceive a game to be more violent feel more presence than those who perceive less violence in the game. Ivory and Kalyanaraman (2007) examined the effects of violent game content on the subjective feeling of presence, involvement, aggressive thoughts, aggressive feelings, and physiological arousal.

            Media form refers to the physical instantiation of the platform being used to play a computer game including the graphics realism of the game itself. It includes the graphics realism and fidelity, the potential use of stereo graphics, the audio quality, and the “immersiveness” of the gaming platform—whether it includes full surround screens (e.g., Hoffman, Prothero, Wells, & Groen, 1998). Sheridan (1992) proposed three determinants of media form: the extent of sensory information (or immersion) of users in the media environment, the amount of control by the user of the sensor mechanisms of the environment, and the ability of users to modify or interact with the environment. These factors have been shown on the left of the schematic diagram of Figure 1. Although the decomposition into just three factors for media form is not meant to be exclusive, the diagram is more than simply theoretical. As described in the next subsection, a number of factor studies based on questionnaires broadly show that these three factors, and their interactions, can be dominant in participants' experience of presence in virtual environments and games.

            FIG. 1. A schematic diagram of the determinants of presence as discussed in the text. Note. The dependencies shown are meant to be illustrative and it is expected that there will be interactions between them.

            Finally, the remaining factor of “user characteristics” relates to the psychological predisposition of users to become immersed in the artificial world of the game. This can include innate psychological tendencies such as the ability to focus or concentrate. We label them as “immersive tendencies” in Figure 1 and we make use of the Immersive Tendencies Questionnaire of Witmer and Singer (1998) to evaluate them in our experiment (see sections 1.2 and 2.3).

            Some caution is needed when interpreting the terminology of “presence” and “immersion” in the literature. The widespread modern use of “presence” is similar to the notion of “telepresence” in some earlier treatments, with telepresence being now reserved for teleoperation and teleconferencing. The concept used here of “immersion” being the physical immersion of the senses in a virtual environment is opposed to some treatments that use “immersion” as a synonym for “presence” itself. For a discussion of these issues of terminology, see McMahan (2003).

            1.2. Measuring Presence and BIPs

            In general, there are two main approaches to measuring presence: subjective approaches, such as those based on interviews or questionnaires, and objective approaches, such as examining participants' movements and speech in video logging or by using direct physiological measurements (Regenbrecht, Schubert, & Friedmann, 1998; Schubert, 2009; Stanney & Salvendy, 1998).

            Questionnaires have ranged from a small number of questions, such as asking participants to rate their sense of “being there” in the computer-generated world (Slater, Usoh, & Steed, 1994), to elaborate questionnaires that traverse the gamut of possible contributing factors to the experience of presence. Several of the latter, such as PQ (Witmer & Singer, 1998), SUS (Slater et al., 1994), and ITC-SOPI (Lessiter et al., 2001), have been widely used in presence experiments and have been subjected to factor analyses over many participants. Some such factor analyses have recovered the spirit of the conceptual model of Figure 1. For example, a factor analysis of the Witmer Singer PQ revealed dominant factors corresponding to “involvement,” “sensory fidelity,” “adaptation/immersion,” and “interface quality” (Witmer & Singer, 1998). Although the PQ is targeted at objective, design aspects of virtual environments, Witmer and Singer are also responsible for a widely used “immersive tendencies” questionnaire (ITQ), which addresses subjective user characteristics (Witmer & Singer, 1998). Reviews of subjective measures of presence can be found in Insko (2003), Stanney and Salvendy (1998), Van Baren and IJsselsteijn (2004), and Youngblut (2007).

            Questionnaires are relatively easy to administer and are amendable to rapid statistical analysis. However, postexperience questionnaires are, necessarily, based on participants' memories of their experience and, furthermore, questionnaire data are usually not applicable to the temporal variation of presence. Among objective approaches to measuring presence, physiological data have included skin conductance, cardiovascular measures, eye gaze, and electro-electroencephalography. Although these physiological measures are more difficult to administer than questionnaires, they do produce continuous data during the actual experience itself. However, there are indications that physiological evidence is most useful for large variations in presence and that subtle variations are difficult to observe (Meehan, Insko, Whitton, & Brooks, 2002; Slater, Brogni, & Steed, 2003). Physiological measures may vary slowly and over a limited range, and their responses may also be due to other factors apart from presence.

            Subjective and objective measures have been used to study BIP: Slater and Steed (2000) and Brogni et al. (2003) used a “speak aloud” technique where participants were asked to indicate verbally, or by pushing a button, when they felt they had made a transition back from the virtual world to the laboratory. Slater and Steed examined logged data from participants' head and hand movements. The Brogni et al. study demonstrated a negative correlation between the amount of presence according to a questionnaire and the number of spontaneous BIPs reported. Spagnolli and Gamberini (2002) used a discursive and interaction analysis of videotaped verbal and nonverbal actions of both the participants and the researcher in their analysis of spontaneous BIPs. Their evidence supported the notion of a smooth model for BIP transitions rather than discrete transitions from the virtual world to the laboratory and provided support for the design and evaluation of “hybrid” media, which combine elements of a real-world setting with display devices.

            In two companion papers, Slater et al. (2006) and Garau et al. (2008) described an experiment where dramatic induced BIPs (system “whiteouts”) were introduced into a virtual experience. Participants' reactions to these BIPs were assessed both subjectively, by interviews and questionnaires, and objectively by electrocardiogram (ECG) and galvanic skin response (GSR). The physiological data, presented in Slater et al. (2006), showed that the induced BIPs could be identified following substantial analysis. The qualitative data from interviews reported in Garau et al. (2008) provided a rich portrait of the temporal nature of the presence experience. In particular, the authors asked participants to sketch their recollection of how their feelings of presence varied over time. The intriguing, hand-drawn graphs that were obtained displayed various patterns of presence degradation (or “impact”) and recovery similar to the slider traces discussed in the next section. In their conclusion, Slater et al. (2006) called for future investigations of different types of BIPs to determine the practical consequences of each.

            1.3. Slider Measurements of Breaks in Presence

            In IJsselsteijn, Ridder, Hamberg, Bouwhuis, and Freeman (1998), the authors introduced a continuous rating of presence in a stereo, 3DTV, environment using a handheld slider. Their method provided a continuous measurement of participants' subjective judgment of their feeling of being present in the virtual world. In its essence, the slider is a subjective measure, but in the continuous data obtained it is similar to objective measures such as movement logs or physiological responses. Participants pushed the slider control away from themselves to indicate an increase in the feeling of being present in the virtual world of the 3DTV. The slider control was also used to separately indicate perceptions of depth and naturalness of depth when viewing the 3DTV, and their results provided support for Sheridan's “extent of sensory information” as being a determinant of presence.

            IJsselsteijn et al.'s (1998) technique had two limitations for its prospective use with computer games in an immersive VR environment. First, participants needed to manipulate a “real-world” slider at the same time as engaging with the virtual experience, and this would have distracted their attention and affected the quality of the experience itself. Second, manipulating the slider meant that one hand was occupied and unable to be used for interaction in the environment itself. We introduced a modified slider technique to address these limitations, the important difference being that the slider assessment was combined with a form of video-cued recall (Hazlett, 2006; Retaux, 2003) immediately after an immersive game experience rather than during the game itself. To conduct our slider measurements, the gameplay of participants was recorded by video-capture software and was then replayed in the virtual environment with the user located in the identical position in the VR theatre—but operating a slider (to recall their feelings of presence) rather than a keyboard (to play the game itself). The idea was that the identical setting of the VR theatre would help participants recall their subjective feelings of presence. The slider assessments were undertaken using a commercial music fader that was modified to have force-feedback on the slider control.

            Figure 2 shows a diagram of the slider control together with typical data trace. Breaks in presence appear as sharp downward movements of the slider trace followed by a more gradual upward movement back to a state of increased presence. These features of the slider trace mirror those reported in the interviews of Garau et al. (2008) and motivate a separate consideration of the impact (downward movement in slider units ranging from 0 to 127) and recovery time (in seconds) associated with BIPs.

            1.4. General Hypotheses

            The following points have been made in the preceding discussion:

            •

            Modern game environments are approaching traditional, immersive VR environments in their sophistication.

            •

            Earlier studies have discussed the concept of presence as being important in the design and analysis of video games.

            •

            Paradoxically, a move to even greater sophistication in gaming in online environments is likely to lead to breaks in presence in the gaming experience.

            •

            An earlier study of BIPs has noted a negative correlation between the amount of reported presence and the number of BIPs.

            •

            Sketches obtained from interviews, and data from slider traces, motivate the analysis of both the impact and recovery from BIPs.

            •

            Earlier work has called for studies of the effect of different types of BIPs on the user experience.

            These points motivate the experiment described in the rest of this article. Key features of this experiment were:

            •

            Dependent variables were the impact and recovery from induced BIPs and the overall number of BIPs (both induced and spontaneous BIPs) recorded by participants. Impact and recovery were determined both by slider measurements and by questionnaires. The number of BIPs was recorded from a questionnaire.

            •

            A number of contrasting BIPs was selected for investigation. These BIPs were motivated by practical concerns as well as from the theoretical determinants of presence in the model of Figure 1.

            •

            A deliberate attempt was made to study the correlation of increased presence with the dependent measures of BIPs using a high-involvement computer game and contrasting it with a low-involvement game. According to accepted models for presence, including that of Figure 1, a high-involvement experience ought to lead to increased presence.

            •

            Individual user characteristics, and individual perceptions of overall presence, were evaluated using questions from earlier, accepted questionnaires (the PQ and ITQ discussed in section 1.2).

            The two general hypotheses of our experiment can be described as follows:

            H1:

            Participants will react differently to different types of BIP. There is no reason to suppose that all types of BIPs would be equivalent in their effect. As an example, it seems reasonable to presume that a major disruption such as a “whiteout” would have a greater effect on a participant's experience of presence than a dropout of the audio channel.

            H2:

            The level of involvement in the game content will affect the experience of BIPs. As discussed, involvement affects the degree of presence and earlier work has indicated an inverse relationship between presence and the number of BIPs.

            Related questions of interest to us in our investigations were the following:

            RQ1:

            How are the dependent measures (impact, recovery time, and the number of BIPs) correlated with each other? Both the dependent measures of impact and recovery time are related to the severity of the induced BIPs. A higher severity of induced BIPs might be associated with an overall drop in the perception of presence. According to the literature, a drop in overall presence should be associated with an increase in the number of spontaneous BIPs (Brogni et al., 2003; Jennett et al., 2009). Thus, it is possible that all three dependent measures could be positively correlated.

            RQ2:

            How are individual user characteristics associated with perceptions of BIPs?

            RQ3:

            Can we recommend the video-cued-recall slider technique to others as a way of investigating presence?

            2. EXPERIMENTAL METHOD

            A mixed experimental design was adopted with main effects targeted at the two general hypotheses H1 and H2. Participants played a high-involvement and a low-involvement game (H2) and induced BIPs were nested inside each game experience (H1).

            The experiment was conducted in a VR theatre with two rear-projected 2.9 m × 2.2 m screens, joined at an angle of 90 degrees and providing an almost 180 degree immersive field of view (see Figure 3). Participants were seated in the region between the screens facing toward the vertex and the game environment was controlled using a keyboard. During the video-recalled-slider evaluation, the keyboard was replaced with the slider and the game experience was played back, in situ, in the VR theatre. The experimenters had full control over the ambient lighting and sound as well as the other programmable aspects of the virtual environment.

            A total of 36 university students participated in the study—18 participants in each of the two treatment groups described in section 2.3. Their ages ranged from 18 to 30 (M = 22.4, SD = 2.9). Recruitment was by advertisement around campus, and each participant received a movie ticket for participation. All of the participants played computer games at least once a month. The protocol was approved by the human ethics committee of the university.

            2.1. Game Environment

            We used two sharply contrasting video-game experiences (a “navigation game” and a “combat game”) as levels of the principal independent variable (“game mode”). We employed a first-person-shooter (FPS) game, originally written for a study of a commercial, online game-engine (Lee & Park, 2004), and ported this game to the two-screen VR theatre. We modified one of the game levels to implement the two, “navigation mode” and “combat mode,” scenarios. In navigation mode, there was no particular mission and no threat of attack. Participants were told that they should explore the environment, which was the interior of a grand, two-story building including a staircase and balcony (see Figure 5). Players had the use of their weapon in this mode, and they could amuse themselves by taking shots at stationary enemy avatars, but these avatars could not retaliate. In combat mode, participants were subjected to continuous attack by enemy avatars, and they needed to engage in typical FPS tactics such as moving quickly, shooting, hiding, and so on. The enemy avatars were under the control of a remote participant who was an experienced player of this level and who tuned the intensity of the attack to be always just at, or above, the level of competence of the player.

            The two game modes chosen for our study contrasted sharply in terms of their level of involvement, their interactivity, and the existence of a goal. Previous studies of presence in violent and nonviolent games compared totally different game environments from the two genres (e.g., Ivory & Kalyanaraman, 2007; Nowak et al., 2008; Tamborini et al., 2004). Our choice of game environments was made to avoid confounding factors such as differences in visual realism, the amount of 2D or 3D fidelity, interaction techniques, sound effects and music, technical sophistication, and so on.

            2.2. BIP Design

            We implemented four different technical anomalies that we labeled a “BIP1” to “BIP4,” as shown in Table 1. Our technical anomalies were designed based on the determinants of the media form contribution to presence discussed in the theoretical model of section 1.1 as well as the likelihood that such breaks might actually occur in real, online game playing. Their parameters were tuned following in-house trials and with regard to other studies (Claypool & Claypool, 2007; Murray, Arnold, & Thornton, 2000; Slater et al., 2006; Wang, Otitoju, Liu, Kim, & Bowman, 2006; Wilson & Sasse, 2000).

            Temporal Presence Variation in Immersive Computer Games

            All authors
            Jaeyong Chung & Henry J. Gardner
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.627298
            Published online:
            21 June 2012

            TABLE 1 Technical Anomolies Used to Induce Breaks in Presence

            CSVDisplay Table

            The first technical anomaly, BIP1, considered frame rate. Generally, frame rate is determined by hardware resources, computing power, or Internet connections. Frame rates can drop suddenly during actual game playing, and low frame rates can significantly affect performance and player enjoyment (Claypool & Claypool, 2007). In terms of our presence model, a drop in frame rate effects the ability of participants to effectively modify the environment (to kill a target) because of the sudden drop in effective visual feedback. Following trial-and-error studies we set the low frame rate to be five frames per second for BIP1.

            The second technical anomaly, BIP2, was a sudden loss of audio. Such a situation might be caused by a bad headphone or speaker connection, a sound-card failure, or a conflict with other software applications, and so on. An audio dropout effects the extent of sensory information presented to the participant thus reducing the immersiveness of the game environment.

            In BIP3, the mappings of the keyboard and mouse controls to viewing and navigation in the virtual environment were suddenly reversed. This anomaly addressed the level of control factor in the theoretical model for presence.

            Finally, a “blackout” anomaly, BIP4, suddenly turned off the entire display, including audio, so that participants were plunged into darkness. This anomaly was similar to the whiteout BIP used in the study by Slater et al. (2006) and Garau et al. (2008).

            During the experiment, the four BIP anomalies were triggered at periodic intervals and each lasted for 3 to 4 s. In navigation mode, the interval periodicity was set to 60 s. In combat mode, we wanted to avoid the possible confounding issue of whether or not a participant was actually engaged in combat at the time of a BIP. Accordingly, a BIP anomaly was not triggered until an enemy was located within a participant's viewing frustum and within a certain threshold distance from the player's avatar. In the case of BIP3 (control reversal) the effect was not triggered unless a participant's mouse or keyboard was active at the time. In fact, it turned out that the time differences between the triggering of BIPs in the two game modes were not considerable due to the continuous nature of enemy engagement in combat mode. As remarked previously, the parameters selected for the intervals and the duration of the BIP anomalies were tuned by in-house trials. Because we had two blocking variables (the order of BIPs and the partipants) we used Latin square randomization schemes that allowed us to block simultaneously on those two variables. We replicated the entire Latin square layout as many times as the limit on the number of participants allowed (using 4 × 4 Latin square with nine replicates to make up 36 participants).

            2.3. Procedure

            The 36 participants were randomly assigned to one of two groups where each group played the game modes in the alternating order: The NavigationF group played the navigation game first and the combat game second and the CombatF group played the combat game first and the navigation game second. Upon arrival at the VR theatre, each participant was given a consent form and asked to read an information sheet describing the experimental procedure and the usage of the game controls, and so on. In particular, participants were introduced to the concept of presence and told that they would be asked to rate their experience of presence.

            In the next part of the experimental procedure, participants were asked to complete a so-called FIG questionnaire. Adapted from the Immersive Tendencies Questionnaire (ITQ) of Witmer and Singer (1998), this questionnaire aimed to measure the innate tendencies of participants to experience presence. The ITQ has a reduced form that comprises 18 Likert-scaled questions, 16 of which can be grouped into well-defined subscales known as Focus, Involvement, and Game. We used questions only from these three subscales in our FIG questionnaire (Focus questions 5, 14, and 29; Involvement questions 6, 8, and 17; and Game questions 10 and 21 from the ITQ), and we kept these three subscales separate for the correlation analysis described in section 6. Responses were solicited on 7-point Likert scales and were checked later for their internal consistency using Cronbach's alpha. The questions are listed in the appendix.

            The third part of the experimental procedure involved training sessions for the game and for the slider control. It was explained that the game was not a completed version and that some technical problems, resulting in breaks in presence, could occur at any time and that, subsequently, they would be taken through a replay of their game and asked to manipulate the slider according to their sense of presence. It was necessary to reveal these details of the experimental procedure in order to attempt to balance the first and second game experiences. A training session of around 4 min was provided to practice the first game mode in the VR theatre. In addition, participants were asked to manipulate the slider with an explanation of its concept.

            The fourth step involved the first game experience and took 6 min. Immediately after this gameplay, participants were taken through the process of video-cued-recall of their game experience using the slider. Following the slider assessment, participants were then asked to complete two postexperience questionnaires. The first, BIP-Rating questionnaire, included two questions that asked participants to identify and rate each BIP according to its impact and recovery time. The second, Overall Presence questionnaire, was adapted from the Presence Questionnaire (PQ) of Witmer and Singer (1998). We used five questions from the PQ for assessing overall presence (PQ questions 3, 18, 23, 26, and 30) and checked for their internal consistency using Cronbach's alpha. The BIP-Rating and the Overall Presence questions are listed in the appendix.

            Following a break of 5 min, the game mode was swapped and the entire procedure was repeated. The slider assessment and postexperience questionnaires were again administered following this second experience, so that each experimental group completed the slider assessment and the BIP-Rating and Overall Presence questionnaires twice—once for each game mode. The full experimental procedure took about 1 hr.

            3. RESULTS

            Our experimental design admitted both within-subjects analysis (treating the CombatF and NavigationF participant groups separately) and between-subjects analysis (treating first experience and second experience separately). In the literature, Freeman, Avons, Pearson, and Ijsselsteijn (1999) have shown that presence ratings obtained for a given experimental condition can be seriously affected by a previous experimental condition. Khanna, Yu, Mortensen, and Slater (2006) argued that this problem is serious enough to discredit within-subjects designs for presence experiments. They pointed out that in a second experimental condition participants will have adapted to the virtual environment and they will also have a deeper knowledge of the nature of the experiment than they had during the first condition. Our starting point in analyzing our experimental results was to be mindful of strong carry-over effects that might occur for the second experience of each participant group. We expected that the second-experience data would not be directly comparable between groups. As shown in Table 2, and discussed next, and we carried out our between-subjects analysis on the first experience only. We considered the within-subjects data separately for each of the two participant groups and we labeled these comparisons as “Within Subjects (NavigationF)” and “Within Subjects (CombatF).”

            Temporal Presence Variation in Immersive Computer Games

            All authors

            TABLE 2 Overview of Results for Impact and Recovery From the Slider and From the BIP-Rating Questionnaire

            CSVDisplay Table

            3.1. Slider Results

            The slider data analysis was completed as follows: Each BIP event was examined to determine the values for the impact score and recovery time—the parameters A and B shown in Figure 2. To estimate these values, we determined three inflection points immediately after a BIP. As shown in the sample slider traces in Figure 4, there is considerable variation in the individual “style” of moving the slider control. A simple statistical method that normalizes for these individual differences in scale is the well-known z score, which transforms data to vary about a mean value as measured in units of the standard deviation. In their study of presence, IJsselsteijn et al. (1998) applied the z-score transformation to each complete slider trace. As we were only interested in the parts of these traces that corresponded with breaks of presence, we tabulated the parameters A and B from the raw slider data and then performed the z-score transformation on each participant's set of impact scores (A values) and recovery times (B values). The price of this transformation is to lose the degree of freedom associated with the absolute magnitude of the slider movements, and this meant that a main effect for game mode could not be determined from the slider data.

            Temporal Presence Variation in Immersive Computer Games

            All authors
            Jaeyong Chung & Henry J. Gardner
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.627298
            Published online:
            21 June 2012

            FIG. 2. A sketch of slider movement (left) and typical traces obtained (right). Note. Participants move the slider control away from themselves to indicate increased feelings of presence in the virtual world and back toward themselves to indicate a decreased feeling of presence in the virtual world (color figure available online).

            FIG. 2. A sketch of slider movement (left) and typical traces obtained (right). Note.             The transformed slider scores for impact and recovery were analyzed using an analysis of variance and Tukey's posthoc tests to investigate the main effect of BIP type and interactions between game mode and BIP type. Details of the slider results are given in Appendix B, section 1, in Figures 6 to 8 and in the top half of Table 2. From Table 2, it is apparent that main effects for BIP type were found for every comparison but that interactions between game mode and BIP type were only noticed for impact and only for the between-subjects (first experience) and within-subjects (NavigationF) comparisons. The BIP types associated with the two significant interactions are listed in Table 2. It can be seen that BIP4 (blackout) was included in both significant interactions and that BIP2 (audio dropout) did not occur at all. The other two BIPs occurred once in each significant interaction.

            No interactions were found for recovery. Indeed, the data in Appendix B show that the p values associated with the recovery comparisons for the between-subjects and the within-subjects (CombatF) comparisons approached unity.

            3.2. BIP-Rating Questionnaire

            The self-reporting of BIPs in the BIP-Rating questionnaire created some issues for the analysis. Many participants gave different labels for the induced BIPs (e.g., BIP1 was variously reported as “flickering,” “lag,” and “low frame rate”), and induced BIPs were usually out of order and occasionally forgotten (in one or two cases, participants were contacted again to clarify their responses). In addition, spontaneous BIPs were often described and rated by participants. The number of these additional BIPs was included in one of the dependent variables in our analysis and is discussed in section. 3.3.

            The Likert-scaled data obtained from the BIP-Rating questionnaire were analyzed using the Friedman test and Tukey's post hoc test with rank sum for multiple comparisons between the four BIP types. The Wilcoxon matched-pairs test and the Mann-Whitney U test were also used for within and between group data, respectively. We note that the use of nonparametric statistics for the analysis of these Likert-scaled data give results that were expected to be less powerful than the slider data.

            Details of the BIP questionnaire results are given in Appendix B, in the box-plots of Figure 9 to 11 and are summarized in the bottom half of Table 2. Like the slider results, significant results were obtained for the main effect of BIP type across both impact and recovery for the between-subjects and within-subjects (NavigationF) comparisons. By contrast, the within-subjects (CombatF) comparison yielded only marginally significant results for the main effect of BIP type. Game mode yielded only one significant result—the impact comparison of the between-subjects (NavigationF) case. As for the slider results, interactions were found for the impact comparisons for the between-subjects and within-subjects (NavigationF) cases. By contrast with the slider data, the BIP type which featured in both of these interactions was BIP3 (control reversal) rather than BIP4 (blackout). In fact, BIP4 did feature in the between-subjects interaction but neither of BIP1 (frame rate) or BIP2 (audio dropout) showed significant interactions in the questionnaire data.

            3.3. Correlation Analysis

            We undertook a correlation analysis of data obtained from the FIG questionnaire, the Overall Presence questionnaire, the number of “additional” BIPs experienced by participants and derived measures of overall impact and recovery from the BIP-Rating questionnaire. The game mode was also included as a correlation variable. The analysis was completed for the first experience only using Spearman's correlation test and the results are shown in Table 3.

            Temporal Presence Variation in Immersive Computer Games

            All authors
            Jaeyong Chung & Henry J. Gardner
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2011.627298
            Published online:
            21 June 2012

            TABLE 3 Results of Correlation Analyses Between Internal User Characteristics (Focus, Involvement, Game from the FIG Questionnaire), Overall Presence (Summed from the Overall Presence Questionnaire), and Derived Measures of Overall Impact and Overall Recovery from the BIP Questionnaire

            CSVDisplay Table

            A check on this analysis showed that there was no significant difference between the FIG subscales for participants from our two participant groups (NavigationF and CombatF), which indicated that these test populations were relatively homogeneous. Furthermore, a post hoc analysis of our data showed that the Focus, Involvement, and Game subscales had Cronbach's alphas of .75, .79, and .81, respectively, and the five questions in the Overall Presence questionnaire had a Cronbach's alpha of .76, thus supporting the use of these subscales as being internally consistent. We therefore derived overall measures of Focus, Involvement, and Game by summing the three FIG subscales separately. A measure of Overall Presence was derived by summing results of all five questions of the Overall Presence questionnaire. Ratings for Overall Impact and Overall Recovery were obtained from the BIP-Rating questionnaire data by summing the Likert ratings for each individual for each of the four induced breaks of presence.

            As previously noted, test participants often described additional BIPs beyond the induced BIPs. These spontaneous BIPs were given labels such as “being killed by the enemy” (both the moment of being killed and the act of having to press a button to revive), “fallacious scene” (broken texture), and “game imbalance” (noticing a logical contradiction such as an armored character having the same number of health points as an unarmored character). In fact, the total number of BIPs reported ranged between four and 10 across all participants with an average of 5.2. We looked at the correlation between this number and the immersive tendency constructs in this analysis

            From Table 3, it can be seen that Recovery revealed a significant negative correlation with the subscales of Focus () and Involvement (). Recovery also showed a significant negative correlation with Overall Presence. The FIG subscales showed no significant association with either Impact or with Overall Presence. The Number of BIPs showed a positive correlation (.23) with Recovery, but this correlation just missed out on being significant. There was a statistically significant correlation between the number of BIPs and the Game subscale that could be interpreted as finding that a more enthusiastic gamer would report more BIPs than a naive gamer. There was significant negative correlation between the Number of BIPs and Overall Presence. As expected for an experiment that contrasted a high involvement with a low involvement game, there was a significant correlation between Game mode and Overall Presence. A further discussion of these results is contained in the next section.

            4. DISCUSSION

            Both slider and questionnaire data revealed several clear trends. In section. 4.1, we start by discussing the main trends occurring in the between-subjects (First Experience) analysis. This is because of the possible existence of large carry-over effects in the within-subjects comparisons—some evidence for which is discussed in section 4.2. Taking the between-subjects analysis separately also makes sense because it can be discussed together with the correlation analysis (which was completed for the first experience only).

            4.1. Trends From the Between-Subjects Comparisons

            The results presented in Table 2, section 3.1, and Appendix B show the following trends:

            •

            A significant main effect was observed for BIP type in both the slider and BIP questionnaire data, confirming general hypothesis H1. Across our data for impact and recovery, it appears that BIP2 (audio dropout) had the least impact and smallest recovery time of all of the BIPs. The other BIP types varied in their importance, and there was some difference in their relative ranking in the slider and the questionnaire data.

            •

            No main effect was observed for game mode in the BIP questionnaire data. Thus it is not possible to confirm general hypothesis H2. As discussed in the next point, there were significant interactions between game mode and BIP type, and it may be the case that cancellations associated with this interaction neutralized any overall main effect due to game mode.

            •

            Significant interactions between game mode and BIP type were observed for impact in both the slider and the questionnaire data. Of the BIP types, BIP4 (blackout) and BIP3 (control reversal) featured in both slider and questionnaire data sets and BIP2 (audio dropout) did not feature in either. BIP1 (frame rate) featured in the slider but not in the questionnaire data. Examining the data for impact in Figures 6 and 9 shows that the impact for navigation mode was higher than combat mode in BIP2 and BIP4 but was lower than combat mode for BIP1 and BIP3. This seems to make sense: Participants in combat mode needed to be very focused on using their controls (disrupted by BIP3) to modify the environment (disrupted by BIP1). So these two BIPs disrupted the core mission (of survival) in combat mode and received higher impact ratings even though combat mode was a higher presence situation than navigation mode. On the other hand, the severity of the other two BIPs may have been more dependent on overall presence rather than core mission. For them, the high-presence condition (combat mode) was associated with lower impact: With a higher presence situation the audio dropout of BIP2 could be more readily ignored, and the blackout of BIP4 may have been more readily viewed as a temporary problem that would soon be fixed. The fact that a different two of the four BIPs had higher impact for each game mode may explain why there was no main effect for game mode in the BIP questionnaire data (because the overall differences between each game mode cancelled out when summed over all BIPs and all participants).

            •

            There was no significant interaction between game mode and BIP type for recovery time across all of the slider and questionnaire data. This seeming independence of recovery time on game mode was an unexpected result of this experiment.

            With regards to the correlation analyses presented in Table 3 and section 3.3 we note the following trends:

            •

            The number of BIPs had significant positive correlations with Game and Overall Recovery and a significant negative correlation with Overall Presence. The positive correlation with Game could be interpreted as enthusiastic gamers being more critical of inconsistencies or imperfections in the environment and thus experiencing more BIPs. The other two correlations are relevant to our related question, RQ1, in section 1.4: A higher Overall Recovery score is associated with a lower amount of Overall Presence and hence more BIPs. The inverse correlation between Overall Recovery and Overall Presence is confirmed in the table. The inverse relationship between Overall Presence and BIPs reported previously in the literature is also confirmed by the table.

            •

            Contrary to our expectation, there were no marked associations between Overall Impact and any of the other variables in Table 3 apart from Overall Recovery.

            •

            There were some interesting associations between the immersive tendencies and Overall Recovery. The correlation results indicate that participants who had higher scores for Focus and Involvement recovered more quickly from BIPs.

            4.2. Trends From the Within-Subjects Comparisons

            In this section, we offer an explanation for trends observed in the within-subjects comparisons based on carry-over effects for the impact of BIPs.

            The trends observed for the within-subjects comparisons might make sense if one presumes the existence of strong carry-over effects in the reported impact of BIPs, except where a BIP during the second experience seriously interfered with the mission of the game participants. In other words, the different levels of involvement in the two game modes did not, in most cases, seem to effect the impact of BIPs that was, instead, largely remembered from the first experience. However, where a BIP in the second experience seriously disrupted the prospects for survival, then participants recorded an increased impact for that BIP. In the specific case of the within-subjects (CombatF) group, the second experience (the navigation game) was one of relative boredom. Participants had already become familiar with the virtual world under conditions of combat. During their second experience, they were left to simply explore this world at some leisure and enemy avatars did not attack. Several participants reported feeling bored in this second experience. However, it can be seen from the box plots of Figure 11 that the median impact values between the two game modes are almost identical. The lower experience of presence associated with the low-involvement second experience does not seem to have been translated into a higher median perception of the impact of BIPs in these box plots—although the variation of the data across the group does change. This explanation is supported by the slider data in Figure 8.

            In the case of the within-subjects (NavigationF) group, neither experience was one of boredom. During the second experience (of combat) participants found themselves under attack within a virtual world that they were already familiar with from the first experience. From the data of Figure 10, it is clear that the two BIPs which disrupted the mission of survival within that second experience (BIP1 and BIP3) were recorded as having greater impact. In fact BIP3 (control reversal) received a relatively benign median rating of 4 out of 7 for the first (navigation) experience, but this jumped to 6 out of 7 for the combat experience. This large increase in the recorded impact of one BIP, together with equal or greater recordings for impact for the other BIPs, led to the one significant main effect for game mode recorded across the entire experiment (see Table 2). It also led to a significant interaction between game mode and BIP type being recorded in the BIP questionnaire data for BIP3. Although BIP1 (frame rate) also received a higher impact rating in the combat experience, this increase was not great enough to be recorded as a significant interaction effect. The slider data of Figure 7 supports this explanation with the exception of the impact ratings for BIP4, which show this BIP to be significantly less in the second, combat experience. In fact, the slider data recorded BIP4 as having a significant interaction between game mode and BIP type. At present, this apparent contradiction in the data is unresolved, although we do note that the box plot for the impact of BIP4 for combat mode in Figure 10 has a longer tail (in the direction of lower impact) than that for navigation mode.

            To conclude this section, we offer the following additional observations on overall trends in the within-subjects data:

            •

            A significant main effect was observed for BIP type across most of the slider and BIP questionnaire data, confirming general hypothesis H1. As with the between-subject data it appears that BIP2 (audio dropout) had the least impact and fastest recovery of all of the BIPs. As with the between-subjects data, the other BIP types varied in their importance and there was some difference in their relative ranking in the slider and the questionnaire data. Although significant main effects for BIP type in the CombatF group were not recorded in the BIP questionnaire data, the p values obtained were marginally significant (p values of .06 and .07), and this, perhaps, reflect the lower power of the questionnaire data compared with the slider data (where the main effect of BIP type was recorded as being significant for the CombatF group).

            •

            A main effect in the BIP questionnaire data was observed for game mode for impact for the within-subjects (NavigationF) comparison. This has been discussed earlier, and it is likely to have been driven by the increased impact of BIP3 (control reversal) in the second (combat) experience. That is, this main effect has in fact been driven by a strong interaction between game mode and BIP type.

            •

            Significant interactions between game mode and BIP type were observed for impact in both the slider and the questionnaire data—but only for the NavigationF case. This has been also discussed earlier. The significant interactions were associated with BIP3 (in both slider and questionnaire data) and BIP4 (in the case of the slider data only).

            •

            As with the between-subjects data, there was no significant interaction between game mode and BIP type for recovery time across all of the slider and questionnaire data. To the eye, the slider recovery data of Figure 7 seems to exhibit an observable difference between game modes. However these differences were not statistically significant. Once again we remark that this seeming independence of recovery time on game mode was an unexpected result of this experiment.

            5. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK

            Our study has investigated how participants experienced induced technical anomalies (BIPs) during gameplay in an immersive VR environment. We have analyzed the effects of two contrasting game modes on the perceptions of BIPs. We have described a new video-cued-recall slider method for reporting the continuous variation of presence that does not interfere with the experience itself.

            The major results of our study can be summarized as follows:

            1.

            Our results show that participants experienced different amounts of impact and recovery from BIPs depending on the nature of the BIPs themselves. That is, our data demonstrated a significant (or near-significant) main effect for BIP type, confirming general hypothesis H1. Our BIPs targeted the media form characteristics of presence in our theoretical model of Figure 1. As described in the next point, it is the interactions of these BIPs with media content (as targeted by using involving and noninvolving game scenarios) which appear to have determined the participants' perceptions of the impact of those BIPs.

            2.

            Perceptions of the impact of BIPs are task dependent. In particular, there is clear evidence that where BIPs disrupted the mission-critical goal of survival in combat (by reversing-controls [BIP3] or reducing frame rate [BIP1]) that there seemed to be an increased impact of those BIPs. In the case of BIP3, this increase in impact was sufficiently significant to result in a main effect for game mode (general hypothesis H2). However, game mode was not a main effect overall.

            3.

            Perceptions of the impact of BIPs do appear to be presence dependent but only when this does not conflict with the dominant task (of survival in combat). In particular, the two BIPs of audio dropout (BIP2) and blackout (BIP4) seem not to have been associated with a disruption of the survival task. Perhaps this is because BIP2 could be easily ignored and because BIP4 meant that participants were not reminded that they were in the process of being attacked when the displays and audio dropped out. For these two BIPs the high involvement (combat) game mode was associated with lower impact ratings across our data. Lower Overall Presence was also associated with more total BIPs in our correlation analysis. This confirms earlier results in the literature (Brogni et al., 2003).

            4.

            Perceptions of impact and recovery from BIPs do not behave the same way across our data (see our related question, RQ1 in section 1.4):

            •

            Intriguingly, whereas the impact of induced BIPs appears to be clearly effected by game mode through its interaction with BIP type (in the data of Table 2 and Figures 6 to 11), the recovery time appears to be more independent of game mode and no significant interactions were recorded for recovery time. We speculate that a possible explanation might relate to the deep immersiveness of the VR theatre. Perhaps it is the case that immersiveness plays a dominant role when recovering from a BIP rather than the involvement of the specific game mode. In terms of our presence model, perhaps it is the case that media form rather than media content has a dominant role in the recovery from BIPs.

            •

            From Table 3, our measure of Overall Impact did not have any significant correlations apart from with Overall Recovery. However Overall Recovery did have significant correlations with Overall Presence and the total number of BIPs supporting the results of earlier work (Brogni et al., 2003).We speculate that, perhaps, the lack of correlations between Overall Impact and those other quantitites might be because Overall Impact was subject to cancellation effects across the four BIPs—two of which were of higher impact and two of which were lower impact overall.

            5.

            The concept of recovery time seems to have been well understood by participants. The BIP rating questionnaire and the slider have yielded generally consistent qualitative results for the way that recovery time varied across game mode and BIP type. The derived measure of Overall Recovery yielded believable correlations with Overall Presence and the Number of BIPs in terms of earlier literature. These observations show that recovery from BIPs takes time and that that time varies depending on factors such as BIP type, game mode, Overall Presence, and the user characteristics of Focus and Involvement. The fact that the slider results agree qualitatively with the BIP questionnaire gives strong support to the conclusion that the relatively slow variation of presence recorded on the slider traces (such as in Figures 2 and 3) is a real phenomenon. That is, user perceptions of presence vary somewhat smoothly in time rather than being discrete jumps between the two alternative “gestalts” of virtual and real (see the discussion in sections 1 and 1.2 and Garau et al., 2008; Slater & Steed, 2000; Spagnolli & Gamberini, 2002).

            6.

            We have presented evidence for the existence of strong carry-over effects in the recorded impact of BIPs. In particular, the case of the within-subjects (CombatF) comparison seemed to show a remarkable carry-over of impact between the first and second experience. If true, this result is interesting for online games designers in that a bad experience of a BIP on one occasion appears to carry over to a subsequent occasion even if (as is the case of BIP1, e.g., in navigation mode) that BIP is not as disruptive to the task being undertaken on that subsequent occasion. Where they are undertaken, future studies of carry-over phenomena will need to be designed carefully and we note, once again, that previous authors have cautioned against within-subjects experiments to immersive virtual environments because of carry-over effects (Freeman et al., 1999; Khanna et al., 2006).

            7.

            In terms of our related question, RQ2, about internal user characteristics, we have noted some interesting results from the FIG questionnaire (a reduced version of the ITQ of Witmer & Singer, 1998). Correlation results indicated that participants who had higher scores for Focus and Involvement had a shorter recovery time from BIPs. There was also a positive correlation between the Game subscale and the number of BIPs, which could be interpreted as enthusiastic gamers being more critical of inconsistencies or imperfections in the environment and therefore experiencing more BIPs.

            8.

            In spite of a small number of inconsistencies, our results indicate a very good qualitative agreement between the our slider data and data from the postexperience BIP questionnaire.

            There were several limitations in our experiment that could be addressed in future studies: We used fixed values of the duration for each BIP and for the (approximate) time interval between them. We used only a fixed set of four BIP types, and we chose only one level for each BIP type. We used abbreviated forms of the ITQ and PQ questionnaires. The number of test participants could be increased. To have some appreciation of the impact of memory on the data obtained, participants should have been specifically asked how well they were able to recall their perceptions of BIPs.

            Our study clearly motivates further research. The research could be extended to other BIP types of interest to games designers. The relationship between the impact and recovery from BIPs needs to be better understood. To study the hypothesis that recovery depends on the immersiveness of the environment, our experiment could be replicated in environments having different amounts of immersiveness. The lack of correlations between our global measure of Impact and the other variables in Table 3 is a puzzle that should be tested further. The carry-over effects in the perceived impact of BIPs should be examined further using careful within-subjects experimental designs.

            One area of future work is to extend the theoretical model underlying our experiment to one for collaborative virtual environments. It is clear that collaboration is one of the major advantages of online gaming, and the set of BIPs studied could be expanded to address those which disrupt that collaboration. IJsselsteijn and Riva (2003), Lombard and Ditton (1997), and other authors provide guidance on how collaboration can be included in models for presence.

            Other studies have looked at the nature of the flow experience (Csikszentmihalyi,1990) in computer games (Cowley, Charles, Black, & Hickey, 2008; Park & Hwang, 2009) and similar environments (Chen, 2006; Park, Nah, DeWester, Eschenbrenner, & Jeon, 2008). An intriguing aspect of these studies are that our combat game mode was tuned to be one of near-optimal flow—the level of combat was set by a remote expert to be just above the level of expertise of the participant so the amount of challenge in the game was high but not so high as to be frustrating. However, our experimental design and our analysis has been targeted at presence rather than flow. There are several ways in which a variant of our experiment could be constructed to study flow. We mention one idea—that participants could be asked to use a slider to indicate whether they felt frustrated (push away) or bored (pull toward) or in balance between the two (the optimal condition of flow).

            Our final related question, RQ3 in section 1.4, was to reflect on the utility of our video-cued-recall slider technique. As mentioned previously, the results of our experiment provided general agreement with the measures of impact and recovery from BIPs derived from the slider and the Likert-scaled data from the BIP questionnaire. In one sense, this agreement is surprisingly good considering the difference in statistical techniques, and statistical power, of the two analyses. The confidence that the general agreement of these two methods of evaluation provide to the overall conclusions of this article are gratifying. However, it is pertinent to consider whether the slider technique, which involved a lot of work to administer and a lot of data processing to analyze, actually yielded more useful data than the BIP questionnaire. In fact, our treatment of the slider data yielded less information than the questionnaire because the z-score transformation eliminated game mode as a main effect for our experimental design. However, it is possible to argue that this transformation need not be applied in the time dimension and that “mean recovery times” from BIPs (in real seconds) could be yielded from a slider analysis. On the other hand, the slider measure of impact was on an arbitrary scale and is not of interest apart from as a relative measure of the severity of BIPs (which can also be obtained from the BIP questionnaire). Our BIP questionnaire was administered after the slider evaluation, and it may be that the process of undertaking the slider evaluation in the immersive VR theatre helped participants to properly recall the BIPs and their reactions to them (similar to the way in which sketches were used to enable the recollections of BIPs in the interviews conducted in Garau et al., 2008). So, even if experimenters do not wish to analyze slider data, they may consider using a video-recalled-slider technique as a means to help participants recollect and articulate their presence experience. In summary, we would suggest that our experiment has provided confidence in the use of a video-cued-recall slider technique and that it could to be studied further in other contexts to understand its trade-offs in terms of the participants' recall of their experience and in terms of the alternative of a simple survey. Of course, it would also be an intriguing study to contrast the slider data obtained with embedded physiological measures as in Slater et al. (2006).

            Today's video games are becoming more realistic, more engaging, and more networked, and they are expanding their range of genres and range of gaming platforms. Considering these fast-paced changes in game technology, it is to be expected that factors which might influence a gamer's sense of presence may increase and become more diverse. Such breaks in presence might even be deliberately employed by games designers to intentionally vary the gaming experience. It is to be hoped that a greater understanding of BIPs during game play will lead to a better design of games and gaming platforms into the future.

            Acknowledgments

            We owe a debt of gratitude to the reviewers of this article who helped us to better communicate the motivation and contributions of this research. We also thank Dr. Hwan-jin Yoon from ANU Statistical Consulting Unit for help in statistical analysis of the experimental results.

            APPENDIX A QUESTIONNAIRES

            Here we list the questions included in the three questionnaires used in the experiment. All three questionnaires solicited responses on 7-point Likert scales.

            The FIG questionnaire, adapted from the Focus, Involvement, and Game subscales of the Immersive Tendencies Questionnaire of Witmer and Singer (1998), was administered before the game experience:

            • FIG-Q1 (Focus subscale): Do you easily become deeply involved in movies or TV dramas?

            • FIG-Q2 (Focus subscale): How good are you at blocking out external distractions when you are involved in something?

            • FIG-Q3 (Focus subscale): Do you ever become so involved in doing something that you lose all track of time?

            • FIG-Q4 (Involvement subscale): Do you ever become so involved in a television program or book that people have problems getting your attention?

            • FIG-Q5 (Involvement subscale): Do you ever become so involved in a movie that you are not aware of things happening around you?

            • FIG-Q6 (Involvement subscale): Do you ever have dreams that are so real that you feel disoriented when you awake?

            • FIG-Q7 (Game subscale): Do you ever become so involved in a video game that it is as if you are inside the game rather than moving a joystick and watching the screen?

            • FIG-Q8 (Game subscale): How often do you play arcade or video games? (OFTEN should be taken to mean every day or every two days, on average.)

            The BIP-Rating questionnaire was administered after each game experience. Based on modified versions of interview questions used by Garau et al. (2008), each question asked participants to identify and rate each Break in Presence according to its impact and recovery time:

            • BIP-Rating-Q1: Were there any moments when you suddenly became aware of the virtual reality theatre area? If you can remember them, describe what triggered these moments and rate each of them with their impact on your feeling of presence.

            • BIP-Rating-Q2: For each of the items you listed in Question 1, how much time was needed for you to feel very involved in the game environment after these events?

            The Overall Presence questionnaire was also administered after each game experience. Adapted from Witmer and Singer (1998), this questionnaire included the following questions:

            • OP-Q1: How compelling was your sense of moving around inside the virtual environment?

            • OP-Q2: How involved were you in the virtual environment experience?

            • OP-Q3: How quickly did you adjust to the virtual environment experience?

            • OP-Q4: How natural did your interactions with the environment seem?

            • OP-Q5: How well could you concentrate on the assigned tasks or required activities rather than on the mechanisms used to perform those tasks or activities?

            APPENDIX B IMPACT AND RECOVERY FROM INDUCED BIPS

            In this appendix we provide the detailed results of the slider and BIP-questionnaire data as discussed in sections 3.1 and 3.2 and Figures 6 to 11 and Table 2. As described in that section, the results presented here are for analysis of variance and post hoc Tukey tests of z-score-transformed slider data for impact and recovery. The results for Likert data from the BIP-questionnaire were obtained using Friedman, post hoc Tukey with rank sum, Wilcoxon and Mann-Whitney U-tests.

            1. SLIDER RESULTS

            In all of the slider results, there was no significant main effect of game mode on either impact or recovery because of the z-score transformation of the data.

            1.1. Between-Subjects Analysis: First Experience

            Impact

            There was a significant main effect of BIP type, F(3, 136) = 8.89, . Post hoc Tukey tests (at .05 level of significance) showed that the mean scores for BIP1 (0.26) and for BIP4 (0.41) were both significantly higher than the mean scores for BIP2 (–0.36) and BIP3 (–0.31). There was a significant interaction between game mode and BIP type, F(3, 136) = 3.43, . According to this interaction, the two game modes had significantly different impact scores for BIP1 and for BIP4 (but not for BIP2 and BIP3).

            Recovery

            There was a significant main effect of BIP type, F(3, 136) = 3.40, . Post hoc Tukey tests showed that BIP4 (0.23) was significantly greater than BIP2 (–0.31). There was no significant interaction between game mode and the BIP type, F(3, 136) = 0.19 and a high value of .

            1.2. Within-Subjects Analysis: NavigationF

            Impact

            There was a significant main effect of BIP type, F(3, 136) = 5.63, . Post hoc Tukey tests showed that the mean score of BIP4 (0.40) was significantly higher than the scores for BIP2 (–0.31) and BIP3 (–0.21). There was a significant interaction effect between game mode and BIP type, F(3, 136) = 2.84, , with the two game modes having significantly different impact scores for BIP3 and BIP4 (but not for BIP1 and BIP2).

            Recovery

            There was a significant main effect of BIP type, F(3, 136) = 2.73, . Post hoc Tukey tests showed that the mean score of BIP3 (0.17) was significantly different to that for BIP2 (–0.34). There was no significant interaction effect between game mode and BIP type, F(3, 136) = 1.15, .

            1.3. Within-Subjects Analysis: CombatF

            Impact

            There was a significant main effect of BIP type, F(3, 136) = 6.02, . Post hoc Tukey tests showed that the mean score of BIP1 (0.39) was significantly greater than the scores for BIP2 (–0.39) and BIP3 (–0.13). There was no significant interaction effect between game mode and BIP type, F(3, 136) = 0.56, .

            Recovery

            There was a significant main effect of BIP type, F(3, 136) = 2.77, . Post hoc Tukey tests showed that the mean score of BIP3 (0.22) was significantly higher than that for BIP2 (–0.32). There was no significant interaction effect between game mode and BIP type, F(3, 136) = 0.11, a high .

            2. BIP-RATING QUESTIONNAIRE

            In the analysis of the BIP-Rating Questionnaire, it was possible to obtain main effects for game mode. However, a significant effect for game mode was only obtained for impact in the between-subjects NavigationF case—all other comparisons were not significant for game mode.

            2.1. Between-Subjects BIP Ratings: First Experience

            Impact

            There was no significant main effect of game mode (with according to the Mann-Whitney U-test), however there was a significant main effect of BIP type, Friedman χ2(3) = 12.57, , and post hoc Tukey tests with rank sum (at .05 level of significance) showed that BIP4 was significantly higher than BIP2. There was a significant interaction effect between game mode and BIP type; the Mann-Whitney U test showed that the impact ratings for the different game modes were significantly different for BIP3 (with ) and BIP4 (with ).

            Recovery

            There was no significant main effect of game mode(with according to the Mann-Whitney U-test) however there was a significant main effect of BIP type, Friedman χ2(3) = 10.40, , with BIP1 and BIP3 being rated significantly higher than BIP2 (according to Tukey tests with rank sum). According to the Mann-Whitney U-tests there was no significant interaction effect between game mode and BIP type.

            2.2. Within-Subjects BIP Ratings: NavigationF

            Impact

            This is the one case where there was a significant main effect of game mode (with using the Wilcoxon matched pairs test). The mean impact score of combat mode (5.03) was significantly greater than that of navigation mode (4.31). There was a significant main effect of BIP type, Friedman χ2(3) = 21.81, , with BIP4 being significantly higher than all of the other BIPs. BIP1 and BIP3 were also significantly higher than BIP2 (according to Tukey tests with rank sum). One significant interaction effect between game mode and BIP type was found for BIP3 which was significantly higher in combat mode (with according to the Wilcoxon matched pairs test).

            Recovery

            There was no significant main effect of game mode (with according to the Wilcoxon matched pairs test), however there was a significant main effect of BIP type, Friedman χ2(3) = 16.51, . BIP2 was significantly lower than all other BIPs (Tukey tests with rank sum). There was no significant interaction effect between game mode and BIP type according to the Wilcoxon matched pairs test.

            2.3. Within-Subjects BIP Ratings: CombatF

            Impact

            There was no significant main effect of game mode (with according to the Wilcoxon matched pairs test). There was no significant main effect of BIP type, Friedman χ2(3) = 7.49, . There was also no significant interaction effect between game mode and BIP type according to the Wilcoxon matched pairs test.

            Recovery

            There was no significant effect of game mode (with according to the Wilcoxon matched pairs test). There was no significant effect of BIP type, Friedman χ2(3) = 7.12, . There was also no significant interaction effect between game mode and BIP type according to the Wilcoxon matched pairs test.
